Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned some about the history of life in the universe.

ORIGINS OF UNIVERSE
SEARCH OF LIFE IN UNIVERSE
Learnt more about topics in general about astronomy but more specifically about the possibility and search for extraterrestrial life.

I learned the basics of astronomy and our understanding of our place in the universe: the history of astronomy, techniques used by astronomers to understand distant stellar systems, the conditions of early earth which were conducive to the emergence of life, the possibility of other life in the universe, and even the ultimate fate of the universe. This class was awesome; I learned so much and it gave me a newfound appreciation and interest in astronomy.
Helped me to open my mind to things I had never thought about in the universe, really cool information taught that will make me seem super smart when I go home for the holidays

I learned a lot about space in general. We covered interesting content from the big-bang (and evidence for it) to the biochemical origins of life on earth. And all in an approachable way for those not so into the hard science-y stuff. Prof Fischer has a great way of teaching complicated material in ways we can understand, and giving us an appreciation for the bigger picture. I learned about how we have and continue to discover planets, the status of our search for life-suitable planets in our galaxy, the scale of Earth in the universe, etc.. It's a fun topic list, but only take it if you think you'll enjoy it throughout.
Our place in Space and Time, some basic history on the origins of life/big bang theory
Learned more about the search for life on other planets, along with basic astronomy.

The course elegantly wove together scientific disciplinesphysics, chemistry, biologyto explore a really engaging problem of whether life exists elsewhere.  I feel much more capable at approaching this question now, and I better understand how we must move forward to develop a better understanding of how life started on Earth and where else it may exist.  Broadly, Dr. Fischer instilled in me a greater appreciation for science as an approach toward answering difficult questions.
I learnt a lot about the universe.
I learned about methods for detecting exoplanets, how to use an orbital simulator, causes for life on earth, and a bit of elementary astrophysics.
Learnt a basic introduction to astronomy
Introductory Astronomy. Survey course that definitely catered to non-stem majors to make an SC credit enjoyable and informative.
A little bit of astronomy, a little bit of chemistry, a little bit of biology, a little bit of physics. Honestly, this course has the syllabus of a gut but does not have the workload of a gut.
I learned many general themes of astronomy, and a lot about exoplanets

I learned about the timeline of life in the universe and how science has concluded when key events happened. We also learned about the early universe, star and planet formation, and history of Earth. The second half of the course focused on learning about methods for detecting other planets and the possibility of life in the universe.

There are probably aliens out there I guess? That was my biggest takeaway from this course honestly. Most of the basic astronomy and biology (yes, this is a part of the course) I learned in high school already, and it was really only after the midterm that we started doing anything that seemed relevant to the main thrust of the course. The different methods of exoplanet and life detection were pretty interesting, but that was a small bit of the course compared to the seemingly endless stream of useless facts we had to memorize for exams with little applicability elsewhere. Overall, kinda fun class and not very difficult, but a lot of the information was frustratingly esoteric.

I learned about how the solar system likely formed, how the Earth formed, how life on Earth came about, how astronomers go about discovering and observing other planets, and how stars form and their role in the universe. Essentially, I gained foundational knowledge about the universe and our place in it. Skills-wise, I became more comfortable with making educated guesses or making estimates as long as they were supported by evidence.
This course offered an awesome overview of the history of the galaxy, life on earth and the ongoing search for life elsewhere.
This class changed the way I see the world around me. I learned some biology, chemistry, physics, and astronomy.
I learned about how the universe came into being, the formation of planets stars, and the methods to discover planets today.

ways of studying stars and planets, how life begins, how to calculate the probability for life in the universe, a brief history of astronomy itself, how to calculate whether or not a planet can host life, how to tell a planet's composition based on distance from star and density, how to run orbital simulations, etc.
I learned how scientists - chemists, biologists, geologists, and astronomers - are trying find extraterrestrial life.
How to discuss basic science terms
A lot about the universe, star formation, how to tell the distance to stars, the origin of life.
I gained critical thinking abilities, a more in-depth knowledge of astronomy and space, and the ability to use my judgement and estimation.
An introduction to astronomy and deeper understanding of whether or not there is other life in the universe.
I learned about orbital dynamics and prebiology. I learned how to read logarithmic graphs and orbital charts.
Really comprehensive understanding of astro. I didn't know it was going to be as engaging as it was.

Basic knowledge about the universe (age, how it formed, etc.), knowledge about stars and their life cycle, how we measure distances between cosmic objects, how life is believed to have originated on Earth, how we detect exoplanets, and how likely it is that there could be life on other planets. And, of course, we learn all the fundamental terms, equations, and concepts that are required for understanding these things.
An introduction to astronomy and understanding how life started on Earth.

This class totally opened to my eyes to a whole new area of study that I have fallen in love with! Astro is so cool and incredible, especially since the field is constantly evolving! I learned fundamental knowledge about the formation of the universe, planetary detection, and earth analog discovery (i.e. probability/possibility of extraterrestrial life)! Super cool and super engaging! I LOVED THIS CLASS!!! I really couldn't recommend it enough!
I learned a lot about Astrophysics and our universe

-Learned how to run computer simulations to glean astronomical data 
-Learned how to use calculations to gather astronomical data
-Basic understanding of star life cycles, estimating likelihood of life on other planets, etc
General information about space as well as a focus on the origin of life and the search for exoplanets and life on exoplanets
So much. This class taught me the basics of star formation, how to discover stars outside our galaxy, and about life on Earth, prehistoric and now.
I didn't't have much experience with Astronomy before this course, so I gained a lot of insight and new perspectives.

This class focused on understanding the origins of life on Earth as well as the possibility for life elsewhere in the universe. In achieving this mission, the course touched upon several foundational concepts--from the formation of stars and planets in our universe and elsewhere, to the building blocks of life and scientific research that studies the preconditions for organic material and possible life. I learned a lot about working in scientific units, reading scientific papers, and the necessary quantitative calculations that go into making a more accurate estimate regarding life on Earth and in the universe.
I learned new things about the universe that I had no idea about. I think my favorite thing I learned is how small are place in space is. I also because a better problem solver.

I knew basically nothing about the universe before this class. If you want to learn the basics about our universe and galaxy and our search for life thus far, this is such a great introductory course.
I learned a huge amount about Astronomy in this class and really understood how life probably came to be as well as the chances of finding it in other places in the Universe.

We broadly covered a huge range of topics, including exoplanet detection, basic biology, and very very basic astrophysics. I definitely walked away with a solid understanding of how we know the things we know about space and the possibility of life existing elsewhere in the universe.
Learned so much about various sub fields in astrophysics. Fascinating content that makes you curious for more.
I learned so much about the universe and exoplanets.
I gained a greater understanding of our place in the solar system and the galaxy.
Better understanding of the universe around me.
I learned a great deal about the origin of the universe and the requirements for the formation of life.

We began the semester learning about the formation of the universe including the stars and the planets. This includes but is not limited to a brief history of the universe, and the formation of elements. Next, we continued in our study of the formation of life on planets analyzing the formation of RNA and DNA on planets. Finally, we concluded the semester studying exoplanet detection methods with the purpose of discovering other habitable planets such as the Doppler technique. By completing this course, I have acquired a better background on the formation of the universe and where we sit in the grand scheme of its history. I have also gained insight on what current scientists and astronomers are doing to discover other potential exoplanets with life.
The class gave both an excellent overview of the main topics in astronomy as well as an introduction to the science behind the development and conditions of early life.
I learned a lot about the value of science and scientific rocesses, even if it isn't ersonally for me, and a broad overview of how modern astronomy works.

This course offered an overview of current scientific knowledge about the possibility of extraterrestrial life. We approached the question through the geological and biological history of Earth, astrophysics, and the techniques currently used to detect exoplanets. In addition to its core material, the course exposed students to the methods of scientific inquiry through a short research project and paper.
Learned about many interesting topics/ideas/facts about our universe
I learned a lot about the interesting aspects of the Universe and gained insight on the detection methods of exoplanets.
Scientific evaluation, reading data, numerical values
I learned about the universe!

Strengths: Some of the material can be interesting

Weaknesses: The material reaches a point that quickly raises the difficulty of the class. It becomes very easy to fall behind and become lost. A lot of specific knowledge is needed for the midterm. (i.e. Specific scientists and their experiments, age of the universe, etc.)

Really great concepts, probably too much focus on biology/chemistry. As an MCDB major this was all fine for me, but I felt that humanities majors didn't really care for this information and it definitely wasn't why they were taking the class.

The lectures were very interesting, the homework assignments were usually straightforward, and there were plenty of resources that helped me understand the curriculum better. I think the planetarium trip was awesome, but I think that it would have been better if it wasn't cloudy (as if that's within the control of the instructors). It was a wonderful class; I can't really think of any weaknesses.
Strengths - DEBRA FISCHER, interesting material

Professor Fischer and the TA's are awesome. They are really friendly, approachable, and accessible via email and piazza. The course is well designed, but in my opinion, spent too much time at the end on the quantitative possibilities of life elsewhere. I actually enjoyed learning about discovery methods and the history of the field more.

Strengths: 9 Psets, 1 midterm, 1 final, 1 short paper; Prof Fischer wants to give you an A even if you don't understand anything
Weakness: The Psets are straight up busywork with little to no meaning. The grading is biased depending on the TA that grades it. The midterm was a piece of cake but the short paper was extremely tedious for no reason. I was told this class was a gut, but it was a trap. THIS CLASS IS NOT A GUT. It's a lot of unnecessary work. Spent about 2 hours a day working on her homework assignments that were filled with numerous typos and discrepancies. Overall, although I only attended class about 5 times throughout the whole semester, I can say that this class is a good 5th class to take if your willing to do the work.

Strengths: Interesting material 

Weaknesses: Sometimes felt like a bunch of not-really-related things were being thrown at us for us to memorize at a surface-level understanding

The course elegantly wove together scientific disciplinesphysics, chemistry, biologyto explore a really engaging problem of whether life exists elsewhere.  I feel much more capable at approaching this question now, and I better understand how we must move forward to develop a better understanding of how life started on Earth and where else it may exist.  Broadly, Dr. Fischer instilled in me a greater appreciation for science as an approach toward answering difficult questions.

My main criticism of the course is that it's a bit memorization-heavy for the midterm and final: Many of the questions were based on factual recall.  But the problem sets and project afforded us an opportunity to analyze a new situation and synthesize our knowledge toward a particular question/objective, which I very much appreciated.

A wonderful science course, particularly if you're a bit hesitant to take one!

The lectures were sometimes hard to understand because it was a lot of new information to process for non-science people. However, Professor Fischer did her best to make everything understandable and accessible. Some of the psets were really hard, and I wish more instruction was given in class about how to approach solving problems like those on the psets.
The main strength of this course was the Professor who was engaged and well organized. The flex book was a nice guide to our studies.

Debra is amazing and very dedicated to teaching. 
Weaknesses are that sometimes the course content is very difficult, and lengthy.
I thought Prof. Fischer did a phenomenal job structuring the course to ensure every student got something out of it

Strengths: Debra Fisher is a power house professor that can make students excited about anything.
Weaknesses: logistically, the course was a bit disorganized -- don't know who's responsibility that is, but losing our papers after they were submitted electronically is a bit unheard of.

I think that the course balanced breadth and depth well, and spending a lot of time on exoplanet detection was very cool. I also liked going to the LFOP. 
However, the units on biochemistry, biology, and previous mass extinctions felt kind of redundant, and I think most students already had a good understanding of those ideas. I think more time could be spent on specific topics in astronomy, and less on background topics in bio/chem.
I also felt like sometimes we were being led to answers (e.g. the chance of life forming on earth, the incidence of life in the galaxy) rather than being free to come up with truly unique WAGS. 
Also, I'm not sure what was supposed to be happening in sections. I never went, and I didn't feel like I was missing anything

Strength: interesting content, good professor. Weaknesses: The course covers such a broad range of surface-level science - from chemistry to geology to physics to biology - that it's an overwhelming a lot to keep up with and memorize for the midterm/final. Lectures were interesting but hard to stay engaged in. Most people are taking this to fulfill their science requirement, so the vibe of the class is generally less enthusiastic.

Strengths: Debra Fischer is amazing, kind, and a strong and organized presenter. Weaknesses: Slow grading, section not always useful, and the information we needed to know for exams didn't seem all that interesting or important to our larger understanding of the universe and our place therein.

I think it is very well-designed insofar as by the time you reach the end, you can see the arc that Professor Fischer had built, making everything come together nicely. Having weekly psets & online quizzes, while sometimes difficult, made me do the readings and actually think through the info I was being presented with. I also appreciated that HW was 40% of our grade, because I put a lot of work into it, and there were also five sessions of optional section or office hours each week that you could go to before the HW was due.

Professor Fischer is fantastic and the textbook (Flexbook) that she wrote is a great source of information. Furthermore the engagement through Piazza was fantastic. Completing the homework and quizzes on Canvas was frustrating sometimes as some questions couldn't be answered using just the course materials.

Strengths - interesting content, accessible to non-STEM majors
Weaknesses - TF grading speed
This course was very well organized to facilitate student learning.

strengths: a good intro to astronomy. Right pacing for beginners. The enthusiasm of the class is great. The emphasis on learning instead of scores is really encouraging. The paper and HW was a good hands-on way to learn about astronomy. 
Weaknesses: the Canvas quizzes should weigh a little less. Sometimes they were very long.

Professor Fischer is a really engaging speaker and was always willing to receive feedback from her students, which meant that she was pretty flexible with deadlines. Her office hours were always really helpful. Professor Fischer also made the class study guides before the midterm and final, which were extremely helpful when studying.

The final paper's peer review process could have been facilitated better because I personally only received feedback from one of my two reviewers, and the feedback received wasn't specific at all. Also, I wish that I could have received feedback on my homework assignments sooner because much of the final paper's content came from the homework, but I didn't know whether or not I had answered the homework questions correctly.

I thought this course did a fantastic job of exposing students to basic astronomy and ongoing efforts to locate extraterrestrial life. I do not have any suggestions on how the course material or structure could be improved. I would recommend, however, that TAs for future iterations of the course provide feedback in a more timely manner.
Professor Fischer is amazing but the content is not very engaging

Strengths: Really nice prof, somewhat interesting material

Weaknesses: Not great TA team (felt like they were not great at explaining material), felt disjointed at times.

A strength was Professor Fisher - she really made the class very engaging and placed the topic within a broader context that was relatable to me. A weakness was the grading of assignments. It would have been helpful to have a faster turnaround so I could know where I stood in the class. I understand that the grad students were probably very busy, but it seems that a schedule or some sort of organization would have been helpful. They were giving back grades very quickly up until mid-way through the semester.

Strengths are that the class is very interesting and is something different from other classes at Yale, which is nice. It is a good break in your schedule that feels like you are learning things that are actually applicable and we may witness in our lifetimes.
It was broken down well for non-science majors, but Drake's equation was confusing at the end.
The course is powered by Fischer's passion. It's seriously contagious. Sometimes I wish it was organized a little better, though.

Strengths:
- While the material could feel a bit dry at times in a given lecture, overall what we were learning was really fascinating. 
- The exams and grading were very fair. 
- Professor Fischer was really passionate about the topic, which was very evident and made class more engaging.
- The class felt low-pressure and not too difficult, and it was clear that Professor Fischer wanted us to succeed and do well. 

Weaknesses:
- The files for the course on Canvas were not very organized at all which sometimes made studying and doing the weekly problem sets a bit difficult. 
- Sometimes Professor Fischer moved a bit too fast in lecture. 
- Professor Fischer knows this, and it wasn't her fault, but there was a period where the grading was very slow.

Its strength is its ability to introduce many easy to understand topics that cover a wide breadth of astronomy. Its weakness would be that it is not the class for anyone looking for a very rigorous or serious introduction to the world of astronomy.

The course was well organized to have a light amount of work (and none of it seemed just like busy work on the psets). Debra is a super fair prof. and she knows most people take this class for the "easy" science credit. She is also not out to get anyone on grading, she genuinely cares that we learn and are engaged with the material. Honestly, the content was super interesting, but the best part about this class is the stellar professor. I love Debra; she is encouraging, sweet yet simultaneously a badass, a feminist, a leader in her field, and a great lecturer! I would recommend taking the class just to have her as your professor!!
This course was my favorite course

Strengths: psets are often a good mix of quantitative and qualitative info; Debra Fischer is kind and understanding and clearly passionate about her work; work is graded fairly; the peer feedback assignment was super helpful
Weaknesses: flexbook at large cant be searched, psets (especially those with simulations) are time consuming; sometimes lectures seemed long and it was hard for me to stay interested as a non-STEM major

This course is very interesting and offers a different perspective than most other courses in that we see exactly how small humanity in the grand scheme of the universe. Debra Fischer is really makes the course great, but it is overall a little disorganized and sometimes the material is so broad it is hard to know what exactly is important to study,
Absolutely disorganized. The TAs rarely got back with me in a timely manner. There was little understanding between the students and the professor on what to do for assignments.
This course was taught well. I thought the HW's were confusing at times.

The course could be improved by reducing the amount of time spent on biology. The important information is about how organic compounds are able to form through natural processes, and how these compounds are common elsewhere in the solar system and the universe.

Overall, I thought this course was well branded as it was advocated. As a non-STEM major, the course did a good job in easing me into the material and fostering an interest in astronomy. I felt that the Flexbook was a unique aspect of the course that served as a reliable, yet digestible source of information. Furthermore, I thought the lectures were useful and fleshed out details in the Flexbook or in the problem sets. Overall, the course was great to engage all sorts of students.
This course was incredible. I have 0 complaints. It was the most interesting course I have ever taken.

A lot of the problem sets and the final research report featured unnecessary grunt work. So while the excercises were very interesting and instructive, it was often frustrating how much time we spent doing tasks (searching for planetary figures and fussing with technology) that took away from my ability to work on other classes and enjoy the material of this class
I think the class was organized in such a way as to make learning easy and teach students about the world. I honestly think this class was built perfectly.

This is a really cool topic, and it was definitely taught at the right level for a bunch of non-science majors. That being said, a lot of times lectures could feel pretty disorganized, and the way that slides were formatted could make it pretty difficult to follow along if you're a visual learner. Overall though, I would say that this is a very solid intro-level class designed to accommodate basically any level of science knowledge.
Material was clear and interesting. Tests were fair, but psets get a little like busy work.

The psets are sometimes a lot more difficult than the exams, but really cool information. The final paper was super cool! Professor Fischer is so cool and such a nice professor! Sometimes class material can get confusing, but that's mainly because she is covering a whole field really quickly.

The course had an engaging lecture, although it sometimes felt too long. I liked the many forms the class took, like the planetarium visit. However, I thought the semester paper was a rather bland assignment that I gained relatively little from. Some of the problem sets felt like busy work.

Strengths: DEBRA FICSCHER IS A QUEEN. My goodness, I cannot express this strongly enough. Not only does this professor know her stuff -- she also genuinely cares that you understand, retain, and engage with the material!! 

Weaknesses: I loved my TA (sam), but the turn around for the psets was much too long. Because the last few psets were particularly important for the final paper, I wasn't exactly sure if my interpretations were correct because I never got feedback.
At times the lectures were a bit hard to follow, but the examples were helpful guiding tools.

The presentation of material and the problem sets all made sense. The optional discussion sessions could be better. They seemed to cover material that was never really relevant to the course and often way outside my level of understanding.

Strengths: exciting lectures, great Professor, passionate TAs who held well organized office hours.

Weaknesses: the methods of evaluation. I was pretty upset by the homework quizzes every week which were less about understanding the material and more about scanning and then reproducing the FlexBook for particular lines of text and praying to all the gods above that your interpretation of the questions wording was right.

Furthermore, the emphasis on rote learning in this course when it came to just neededng to spew out numbers like the age of a body in the universe or that of some phenomenon was rather annoying. I felt that the same points, devoted to an essay or math question would have tested my understanding of this course a lot better.

The professor makes the material easy to understand and engaging, through the structure and with her teaching style. A weakness was that I thought the final paper could have been structured a little differently. I think it would have been beneficial for it to be more in depth.

I think that this course does an excellent job of providing resources to review when trying to understand the material and to complete your homework. The lectures were generally engaging and the professor was generally fascinated by her work which made it easier to listen to. The lecture notes were posted online and our online textbook accompanied each lecture and allowed us to gain a second source on the material. Both of these materials contained all of the information to complete our homework which was very fair, still requiring us to decipher the material. Discussion sections also allowed us to ask questions about the material or our homework which was good, also it wasn't mandatory which was nice so no student felt compelled to attend.The midterm and final exam was also created very fair relative to the material covered during the semester. The study guide clearly outlined any information that would have to be known for each exam. The only confusing part of the course came when we started using the orbital simulator and weren't sure if our results were correct. This caused confusion and maybe this could be improved if there was a better manner in which we could check whether our data was on the right track rather than having every student email the professor or TA.
Course is overall very strong. I think that my only complaint was that the Psets felt like busywork rather than active learning.

I think section should be mandatory, and more feedback on the aer would have been useful - however, the rofessor was consistently engaging and tried to make information as accessible as ossible. The flexbook could do with some assessments and udates, but overall I really enjoyed it.

This is an excellent science credit, and a good class if you are simply interested in the search for extraterrestrial life. Professor Fischer is a remarkable teacher, and the course is admirably designed to be interesting without being overly difficult or monotonous.
Wasnt always clear where answers to homework were located
One of the weaknesses was not having sections. They could have been useful to clear up information that was discussed in the lecture.
Slower going through problems in class that will show up on hw
The course is almost perfect.

Would highly recommend ASTR130 to any student regardless of major. If you need a QR, it's good for that. If you're a STEM major, you can still learn some cool concepts/ideas and not have to work terribly hard. This class is definitely not a gut since you have to put in the work, that being said if you do the work you'll do fine in the class. The material is (mostly - besides the biochem stuff) really interesting and you learn a bunch about the universe. Fischer is also a great professor - she's a pioneering doctor in STEM and knows her stuff.
Yes - the topics are fascinating and the teaching was brilliant

I would definitely recommend this course, especially to those who are generally interested in the universe and would like to know more about how our solar system came to be, how life emerged on earth, and the basics of astronomy. The assignments weren't too tough, but at the same time, I learned quite a lot. Also, Debra Fischer is a wonderful instructor with such positive energy!
YES. Debra Fischer is an awesome professor who really cares about her students and wants them to succeed. Also, the information is really cool and very eye-opening!
I would recommend if you are interested in the topics and looking for a manageable science credit. That said, the psets and online quizzes can take a long time.

I recommend this course to those that are looking to be clueless for a majority of the semester and is willing to grind the day before the midterm and final to get that A. Because that's what I did :)
Yes, this is a good science course with a very strong instructorone who will care deeply about your learning.

This is a very comprehensive and interesting course for non-science majors.  If you are looking for a distributional credit or just want a broad overview of the rise of life on Earth, I would highly recommend this class!  As a humanities major who doesn't know much about science, I was very satisfied with how the (manageable) level of depth in this course kept me engaged the entire semester.

Yes! Professor Fischer is amazing, and even though I struggled a lot in the class, I now how a newfound appreciation for astronomy. If I was not so bad at science I would even consider taking more astronomy classes.

I would recommend this to any student interested in learning more about Astronomy. If you put in the work asked of you, it is a decent amount of work with online quizzes, readings, and fully graded problem sets each week.
Yeah.
If you're looking for a science credit absolutely take this course!! Great way to learn something about astronomy without feeling like a fish out of water
If you're non-STEM and want an Sc credit, this is a good way to get one. Be warned that it's not exactly a gut -- the work load can be a lot especially in a 5 credit semester.

This course is relaxing without being a total gut, and the content is usually very interesting. Weekly psets can take a significant amount of time, but if you go to class, the content is generally well-taught and interesting. For humanities majors who need science credits but also want to learn some new things, I would highly recommend this class!

I would recommend this course to students who are generally interested in astronomy, the origins of life, and/or exploring life on other planets. You should be prepared to cover content related to chemistry, biology, physics, geology, and astronomy.
Yes and no. Lectures were engaging, and Professor Fischer is fantastic, but the material you learn isn't all that interesting or useful.

Yes, definitely. As a humanities major, this course was definitely challenging, but honestly, if you do the readings, give some time to the HW, and study reasonably for the exams, you'll learn a lot and do well.
Take this class. I did not take it for the science credit having completed the Physics 200 track, and I really enjoyed it for the awe it inspired it me.

Yes, this course is a great opportunity to learn about something interesting, and Professor Fischer is absolutely incredible. If you can take this course, do it. It is not a gut, but she is an awesome teacher and if you pay attention in lecture everything is pretty easy.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this class to another student. It's a great class for non-science majors.

Yes! This is a good course to take for SC credit. Note that it is not a gut. But if you do the HW, you pay attention to lecture, you go to section--you'll be fine. Also, you genuinely learn so much about the universe. Be careful not to be careless on the quizzes. They can really bring your grade down.

Yes, especially if you are a humanities/social science major looking for a really interesting but not too demanding science credit. You will have to do the work - complete the weekly readings, p-sets, and quizzes for this class - but once you put in the effort, this class will be really rewarding. I had no idea of Yale's astronomy resources or any knowledge of the universe before taking this class but feel that I am definitely walking away with the knowledge of the origins of our universe and how the search for life has progressed over time.
I would recommend this class to another student looking for a manageable science credit. Professor Fischer is inspiring and the course material is approachable.
Yes for non science people
Not especially.

I would recommend this course. It is a great way to fulfill your SC requirement and the workload is not overbearing. It's a good course for humanities majors who are looking to get an understanding of astronomy that can be built upon at any point.
I would recommend it because it is a very intriguing topic and Prof. Fischer is awesome.
Yes, it's especially good for non-science majors interested in space.

I would recommend this class, especially if you're looking for a science credit. I actually took this class as a STEM major and still enjoyed it. It's not too much work, the stuff you learn about is pretty fascinating, and Professor Fischer is wonderful, passionate, and kind professor. There were some organizational problems in the class (I discussed in strengths and weaknesses), but overall I thought this was a great class.
Yes, unless they are seriously considering astronomy then I would recommend a harder class.

YES!!!!! I really would recommend this class. I think people go wrong in their approach to the class bc they are solely in it for the easy science credit. Honestly though, there is no such thing as a science gut where you can put 0% effort in and expect to get the A. If you attend class (and listen to lecture) and do the Psets, its an easy A. Many people in the class complained that it was super hard, but that is bc they literally never came to class. It is super easy to do well, EXTREMELY interesting, and Prof. Fisher is INCREDIBLE. PLEASE DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND TAKE THIS CLASS!! PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE!

This is a decent science gut. The grading, material, and tests are super straightforward and easy - but the pset workload is a lot. Make sure you have a study group, sometimes getting through the workload completely alone is nearly impossible because the material is very confusing at first glance. But grading once again is super lenient. All the important material is in the slides which are released online and in the textbook so lectures arent 100% necessary.
Yes I recommended it to my fellow classmates

If youre already interested in space and willing to do some math and tedious simulations, yesgreat instructor and interesting subjects. If youre mainly looking for a science credit, probably not... you can do well if youre trying your best, but you will probably be stressed or frustrated along the way.
Yes
Yes this is a good Sc credit to take if you are not a stem major and need a Sc credit. It is not quite a gut though and will require some effort.

I would absolutely not recommend this class to another student. The only motivation one would have in taking this class is if it was a gut. This class fails even in this capacity. The only students who would consider this course a gut are STEM majors. For humanities majors, this is a bad course to take. This course is disorganized and comes with more work than should be necessary. If you are to take an astronomy course, I would suggest taking a course taught by Michael Faison. His class is probably as difficult as Professor Fischer's, but it is at least organized properly. Debra Fischer is a nice person and clearly very knowledgeable. But the way she organized this course was not conducive to learning.
Yes! Absolutely.
Yes, it is a great course.

This course is great for any student who wants to have an existential crisis and a better understanding of the universe. My view about the existence of life in the universe has radically changed as a result of taking this course. The material is extremely interesting, as well as important.

I think this is a fantastic course for any student and a great Sc credit to take! As a non-STEM major, I was a bit intimidated about the possible physics and mathematics involved in the course, but Professor Fischer is a great and understanding instructor who will really walk you through all the necessary steps. I ended up learning a lot about astronomy and thinking about large questions that I had never thought about previously. Problem sets were interesting to do and really prepared you for the exams (which were straightforward). A great class to take, and I am glad I did!
I think everyone should take this class. It is very important for understanding the universe.
Yes

This class isn't a gut but it is amazing. You will actually learn how astronomy is done and about the Universe. It is classes like these and professors like Debra Fischer that make Yale special. Classes like these are perfect for non-stem majors who actually want to learn something with their science credit.

I would, but as long as you go into it understanding that this is not a gut. It's definitely intended for non-science majors, but you do have to show up and put in the work in order to do well (you can't just blindly coast through). It's a really interesting topic, though sometimes lectures felt a little all-over-the-place/ hard to follow.
Definitely would recommend it. If you need a science credit this is interesting and not overwhelming, but doesnt feel like a waste of time.
Be prepared to do a lot of work for a science credit. I would recommend just for Debra though.
Ya! It's really cool if you want to learn about space! Some really interesting material.
I would recommend this course to another student, particularly a humanities-oriented student looking to fulfill a science requirement.

Yes - a very interesting topic taught by a professor who's engaging, energetic, organized, and really smart and knowledgable. While this is an astronomy course, related chemistry, physics, and biology were tied in which made things especially interesting.

YES. Take it from someone whose high school chemistry curriculum was less than stellar, who never even took calculus or physics, and who has never had exposure to astronomy-- YOU CAN TAKE THIS CLASS BECAUSE DEBRA FISCHER WILL NOT LET YOU FAIL. If you put in the work and the time on the psets, go to section (which are more like office hours than anything else) when you need help, and even email Professor Fischer if you have questions, you will succeed. Though I was skeptical of the math at first, there really isn't that much at all. The only time you'll really have to do calculations is during the weekly open-book, open-note, untimed HW quizzes. The midterm and final were very fair, and the study guide the TA's provide is incredibly helpful if you gather a group together and fill it out beforehand. In terms of material, it was awesome. I never learned about astronomy in high school, so learning about the Big Bang theory, extinctions, exoplanets, and planet detection was AMAZING, especially because it was taught by someone so integral to the field. Take this course. You won't regret it.
I'd recommend it only if you are interested in the topic.
Yes. The material was very interesting and taught by a very engaging professor.
Yes. I thought it was very interesting and not stressful.

I think that this is a great course to take for astronomy and non-astronomy students alike. You cover a lot of bases that give you a broad picture on the exploration for life in the universe which was cool because it's something that we generally ignore and take for granted. For the most part, the course is organized well to facilitate learning and you have the ability to contact the professor or TAs with any questions. The problem sets and online quizzes follow the professor's online textbook so they shouldn't take too long. The exams are also designed fairly with a study guide that should be completed prior to the exams. This will ensure a really good grade on the exams. Professor Fischer truly made the class more enjoyable even if some of the material was a little more dry. She was really passionate about her work and tried to keep the class involved which was really admirable.
I would reccomend this course to any student who wants an overview of astronomy and is interested in the possibility of extraterrestrial life.
robably, if they were looking for an accessible/ kind of interesting science course or if they wanted an intro to astronomy.

I would certainly recommend this course, especially as a science credit. I found the material accessible and interesting, and Professor Fischer was committed to helping students learn. I was very impressed by the course as a whole.
Yes
Yes I would recommend this course. Although the topics and information seem out of this world (pun completely intended) at first, you learn many interesting facts and knowledge about the universe.
Good intro to astro
Must take class! You may find yourself majoring in astronomy after the class. Professor Fischer is the best!
